Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the serious decline in razor clam stocks in Irish waters; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 43, 54 and 106 together.

I share the Deputy's concern about the emerging razor clam fishery. My objective is to ensure that it is managed and developed in a way which ensures the conservation and sustainable exploitation of razor clam stocks.

At my request preliminary research on the fishery has been undertaken by Bord Iascaigh Mhara and the Marine Institute. Work is continuing on a range of issues, notably the extent and location of stocks and spawning season. My Department is working closely with both agencies to develop and put in place the research and management strategies required to support the sustainable exploitation in the interests of the fishermen themselves and the long-term future of the resource.

In addition, and having regard to the precautionary principle, I have asked the Department to finalise management measures, including legal controls, as a priority which will regulate fishing for razor clams and prevent excessive exploitation of stocks.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the reason the elections to the regional fisheries boards have been postponed; the date on which these elections will now be held; the plans, if any, he has to introduce reforms of the boards in advance of the elections; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: I have decided to postpone the elections to the regional fisheries boards for a further year to enable me to complete my review of the inland fisheries services and implement the necessary legislation to underpin appropriate organisational and operational changes over the coming months. The postponement will mean that the elections to the boards are now scheduled for December 1999.

The Deputy will appreciate that to secure the future of this very valuable and unique resource it is critical to address in a comprehensive manner, for once and for all, the difficulties and problems that have detracted from the effective operation of the boards and generally inhibited the development of the fisheries. It is my intention to announce early in the new year the changes I propose to implement and an opportunity will be provided in this House to discuss them in detail.

My review will address the operational and structural arrangements of the Central and Regional Fisheries Boards. I am in particular concerned about the relative roles and responsibilities of boards to ensure that the services are delivered in a more effective and efficient manner. A second concern of mine is to ensure that the composition of the boards adequately reflects both the interests of those with a direct involvement in the fisheries as well as the wider public desire for the optimum development of the inland fisheries resources, particularly in our major catchments. As part of the review I am also examining a number of other issues affecting the long-term development of the sector, including planning and reporting process, and accountability and resource allocation.

I do not want to discuss any further details of the review at this time until I have completed my considerations, but as I have said, there will be an occasion for further discussion in the coming months.
A copy of the draft order postponing these elections was laid before the House on 26 November and I will be asking the house to approve its terms shortly.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: if the planned target will be achieved in new forestry plantations during 1999; and the percentage of that total acreage that will consist of the broad leaf varieties.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The planting target set by the strategic plan for the forestry sector is 25,000 hectares annually to the year 2000 and 20,000 hectares annually thereafter to the year 2035. Planting in 1997 at 12,000 hectares was substantially below target.

While it is not possible at this stage to indicate the precise level of planting in the current year, it is likely to be somewhat higher, in the order of 14,000 hectares. Current expectations are that broadleaf planting will account for approximately 20 per cent of total planting.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the safety measures, if any, in place for the protection of the public in close proximity to sea shores, canals, lakes and maritime in general; if he will review the safety facilities in place on the northside of Dublin Bay; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: My Department plays an important role in maritime and water based safety with the goal of preventing as far as possible the loss of life at sea by establishing and enforcing high safety standards and providing effective emergency response services.

My key objectives in this area are to ensure that vessels meet accepted international safety standards; to improve marine safety culture and awareness; and to ensure the provision of an efficient and effective marine emergency service.

In regard to the latter objective, I have recently extended the remit of the Irish Marine Emergency Service to include inland waters and I will shortly be bringing proposals to Government with a view to developing the service into a coastguard.

The main strategies in place to achieve these objectives are adopting and implementing updated safety rules and regulations in accordance with accepted international standards; supporting the adoption of high international safety standards by the International Maritime Organisation, the EU and other international organisations; developing and using the services of my Department's Marine Survey Office and the Marine Radio Surveyors' Office to survey vessels and enforce standards; promoting marine safety, in association with other safety agencies and sectoral and voluntary groups; providing a marine emergency service through public and voluntary bodies, the co-ordination of those services and co-operation with other states in the operation of emergency services; co-ordinating with other services including the Garda, hospitals, etc. in relation to major accident response plan; and the provision of a range of navigational aids and communication network.

While I am satisfied that this approach is an essential component of the national and international strategy to advance maritime safety, my Department is not primarily concerned with the provision and maintenance of safety facilities (other than those needed for the rescue services) on the northside of Dublin Bay or elsewhere throughout the country. Safety facilities are the responsibility of those authorities and organisations charged with the management and development of discrete land, shore and water based areas and resources.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the steps, if any, taken to minimise dangers to marine traffic arising from possible problems for computer dependent navigation systems and rescue operations arising from the millennium bug; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The maritime safety committee of the International Maritime Organisation at its sixty-ninth session considered the need for the maritime industry to address the Year 2000 problem. The committee subsequently issued Maritime Safety Committee Circular 868.

To ensure that all shipowners, shiprepairers, masters, chief engineers, all ship's officers, skippers, harbour authorities, ship agents, terminal operators, yachtsmen in Ireland are fully aware of the contents of the IMO's MSC Circular 868, my Department has issued a Marine Notice (No. 20 of 1998). A copy of the notice will be forwarded to the Deputy.

I should mention that I am advised by the Commissioners of Irish Lights that they have taken the necessary steps to ensure the integrity of aids to navigation around our coasts after the changover to the year 2000. I am also satisfied that the Irish Marine Emergency Service (IMES) of my Department has alerted rescue service providers under the direct control of the IMES and those providing dedicated services of the need to ensure that rescue services continue to operate satisfactorily during the critical period.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Global Marine Distress and Safety Systems.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the status regarding the introduction of the global marine distress and safety system in February 1999; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The Global Maritime Distress and Safety System (GMDSS) was introduced by the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) on 1 February 1992, for all merchant vessels required to comply with the Safety of Life at Sea (SOLAS) Convention, 1974.

New vessels constructed on or after 1 February 1995 are required to comply fully with GMDSS requirements. These requirements are implemented in Ireland by means of the Merchant Shipping (Radio) Rules, 1992, S.I. No. 224 of 1992.
With effect from 1 February 1999, all merchant vessels will be required to comply fully with GMDSS requirements, which means full compliance with the Merchant Shipping (Radio) Rules, 1992.

MainHeading.P: With regard to the implications for fishing vessels, Council Directive 97/70/EC requires that specific categories of fishing vessels of 24 metres in length and over will, in accordance with Chapter IX of the Torremolinos Protocol, have to install full Global Maritime Distress and Safety System (GMDSS) radiocommunications equipment appropriate to their sea area of operation with effect from 1 January 1999 in respect of new fishing vessels of 24 metres in length and over and from 1 February 1999 in respect of existing fishing vessels of 45 metres in length and over. The Attorney General's office is currently settling draft regulations prepared by my Department to give legislative effect to these provisions.
For the benefit of seafarers, my Department has issued Marine Notices (Nos. 5 and 22 respectively) during the year on the subject of GMDSS, copies of which are appended for the Deputy's information.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Marine Accidents.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the strategy he will adopt in order to ensure the safety recommendations following the sinking of the fishing vessel MV Carrickatine are implemented; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: if he will make a statement on the report of the Marine Survey Office on the loss of the MFV Carrickatine; the action, if any, he will take arising from the report; when he will bring proposals to Government arising from the report of the investigation of marine casualties policy review group.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 49 and 64 together.
A report on the investigation of the loss of the fishing vessel Carrickatine, undertaken by the Marine Survey Office of my Department, was published on Monday, 9 November 1998.

While this report sets out fully the efforts made to investigate this tragic incident, sufficient evidence has not been found to enable the investigation to establish the cause of this terrible tragedy.

The principal findings of the report are as follows: it has not been possible to establish what caused the loss of the Carrickatine as there is insufficient evidence to support any theory which might explain her loss; it concludes that the likelihood was that the vessel was lost very quickly with the crew having insufficient time to use the liferafts or lifesaving appliances; while no trace of the vessel or her crew has been found to date, some debris, identified as coming from the Carrickatine, was recovered but did not reveal any information on the possible location of the vessel.

MainHeading.P: The report makes recommendations aimed at improving the general safety of fishing vessels. Chief among these is the introduction of comprehensive legislation to cover the construction, stability and equipment (including radio) requirements, for fishing vessels of all sizes. It also recommends, as a matter of priority, that the fitting of emergency position indicating radio beacons (EPIRBs) be made mandatory on all but the smallest of inshore fishing vessels. The beacons emit radio signals when activated or on contact with water. The fitting of liferafts should also be mandatory on all fishing vessels and they should be secured by hydrostatic release units so they can float-free in the event of the vessels sinking.

The Government attaches particular priority to the issue of fishing vessel safety and I am taking steps to ensure accelerated progress with regard to the implementation of the recommendations of the Fishing Vessel Safety Review Group, particularly in the area of fleet development. This group was established following the tragic loss of the Carrickatine. The programme being pursued following the review group's report of May 1996 is as follows.

The report of the review group indicated that in the absence of incentives for the renewal of the fleet there would be little improvement in the age structure and safety status of the fleet. Accordingly, I have given top priority to the introduction of the programme for the renewal of the whitefish fleet. The programme involves a grant aid support scheme and tax incentives are provided for in the 1998 Finance Act. The programme is designed to promote investment in the whitefish fleet with the introduction of a number of new and modern second-hand vessels into the fleet. In this connection, I recently approved over £12 million in State-EU grant and aid supporting investment of over £50 million for the introduction of 31 new vessels into the whitefish fleet. I propose to shortly announce funding towards a number of modern second-hand vessels. In addition, a targeted modernisation scheme and support for essential safety equipment for vessels will modernise the vessels in the fleet and contribute to improved safety.

I would, in particular, draw the attention of the Deputy to the vessel safety equipment scheme under that programme, which provided for grant aid of 50 per cent for the purchase and fitting of essential safety gear. I have announced three rounds of approvals to date under this scheme. I consider this vessel safety equipment scheme to be of vital importance. The aim of this scheme is to encourage vessel owners to fit out vessels with specific on-board safety equipment. Improved safety equipment on board vessels can play a vital part in the ongoing battle to protect life at sea; the recent tragedies at sea bring home to us all the perilous working conditions that fishermen endure.

I am generally very pleased at the high level of interest in the programme for renewal of the whitefish fleet. It underlines the appetite and need for reinvestment in the fleet right around the coast and confirms that the incentives on offer are proving attractive to a wide range of fishermen. I would, nevertheless, strongly encourage fishermen to avail of this unique funding opportunity to install vital safety equipment. I am determined to ensure that the scheme fully delivers on the Government's objectives to revitalise the whitefish fleet and to support safety, jobs and competitiveness in the sector to the benefit of our coastal communities.

Concern was expressed by the review group at the number of unregistered fishing vessels operating in Irish waters, many of which are small and in poor condition. The group considered that these vessels constitute a serious threat to safety and recommended that this situation be addressed. Under a special scheme approved by the European Commission, the position of previously unregistered vessels in the fishing fleet is being regularised. Over 600 of some 900 applications under the scheme have been approved for a licence and it is hoped that all of the remaining applications will be processed by the end of this year. The criteria under this scheme for registration require, among other matters, that vessels undergo a condition survey report in order to ensure that the vessel is safe and seaworthy. This represents a significant improvement in our safety regulatory framework and in our safety standards for small fishing vessels in particular.

Safety training, which is vital to protect the lives of fishing vessel crews in the event of an accident at sea, continues to be provided in an accessible manner through BIM's two mobile training units in response to demand at various locations around the coast. In addition, the construction of a new fisheries training centre in Castletownbere is nearing completion. The centre, which will deliver safety skills instruction to fishermen in the south coast region, is targeted to be operational in early 1999. The principal objective of BIM's coastal training programme is to generate a health and safety culture within the small scale fishing sector in particular.

Funding under the EU's Small Scale Coastal Fisheries Programme has been secured towards a new training initiative aimed at the spouses and families of small scale coastal fishermen. It is hoped that the relatives of fishermen can exert a positive influence in the promotion of good safety practices on board small fishing vessels. This pilot initiative, which is being run by BIM in co-operation with Údarás na Gaeltachta, Comharcumann Inis Méain Teo. and Meitheal Forbartha na Gaeltachta, will target 12 venues over the course of 18 months.

Considerable progress has already been made in the field of onshore marine radio communications. My Department's Irish Marine Emergency Service has arranged for the installation of new medium frequency transmitters at Rosslare and Belmullet with enhanced radio coverage and improved emergency response for fishing vessels operating in the Irish Sea and off the north west coast. In addition, my Department has recently placed a contract for the installation of VHF digital selective calling (DSC) equipment at coast radio stations and other VHF sites around the coast and this work is due for completion at the end of next year. Ireland will then be in a position to declare an enhanced area (known as an A1 + A2 Sea Area), under the Global Maritime Distress and Safety System (GMDSS), which will facilitate automatic distress signal reception from vessels fitted with VHF DSC working in or transiting our search and rescue area of responsibility.

The review group identified a need for a substantial improvement in safety awareness among Irish fishermen. In recognition of this requirement, my Department's marine safety working group has published three practical information booklets specifically for fishing vessels. These user-friendly publications deal with machinery failure, man overboard procedures and emergency procedures. Furthermore, it is intended to shortly publish GMDSS guidelines for small boat users, including fishermen, in European waters. The promulgation of this series of safety information booklets can play an important part in fostering an ethos of safety consciousness in the fishing industry.

Notwithstanding the ongoing improvements in the areas of fleet development, safety training, on-shore marine radio communications and safety awareness, a programme is under way to underpin the development of a safety culture in the fishing sector through the introduction of the comprehensive safety regulations recommended by the review group.

The preparation of the proposed safety regulations governing fishing vessels is well under way. Regulations have already been drafted to implement European Council Directive 97/70/EC setting up a harmonised safety regime for fishing vessels of 24 metres in length and over. These regulations, which are currently being finalised by the Attorney General's office, cover, inter alia, construction, stability, machinery, fire protection, life-saving appliances and radio communications. Vessels under 24 metres in length will also be addressed by the introduction of regulations for appropriate size categories of smaller vessels operating out of our fishing ports.

Draft radio rules have also been prepared, specifying the radio communications equipment, including emergency position indicating radio beacons, to be carried on all sizes of fishing vessels. I propose to introduce these rules, which are currently being finalised, at an early date. I also intend to bring in new regulations for the crews of fishing vessels, which will cover safety training and increased manning requirements, in line with the review group's recommendations in this regard.

In the context of health and safety in the workplace, the Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment, who has responsibility for the Health and Safety Authority (HSA), is to shortly introduce regulations to give effect to European Council Directive 93/103/EC on the minimum safety and health requirements for work on board fishing vessels. These regulations, which are being prepared in consultation with my Department, will provide for its joint implementation by the HSA and my Department, having regard to respective areas of competence.

My Department, and Bord Iascaigh Mhara, together with the Health and Safety Authority where appropriate, will continue, in partnership with the fishing industry, to implement the safety programme outlined above. Our shared objective is to ensure that the priority now given to improving and maintaining safety standards will continue as a permanent and integral part of the management of our fishing fleet.

I have already accepted the general thrust and content of the recently published report of the investigation of Marine Casualties Policy Review Group which was set up to review the existing policy, procedures and legislative framework for maritime casualty investigation in Ireland.

The key recommendation of the review group is the establishment of an independent marine casualty investigation board, with enhanced powers to investigate marine casualties and to expeditiously publish reports of the board's findings.
Drafting of a Bill to introduce the required legislative framework to implement this key recommendation is under way in my Department and I intend bringing proposals to Government in the new year.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the moneys he will provide for improvement works, including dredging and reconstruction, and also an extension of the pier at Helvick Harbour, County Waterford,.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The harbour infrastructure at Helvick is owned by Waterford County Council and development or maintenance works are, therefore, the responsibility of the local authority in the first instance.
I understand that the Department of Arts, Heritage, Gaeltacht and the Islands have provided financial assistance in the current year to Waterford County Council towards some works at Helvick.
My Department has, to date, received no current proposals from the local authority for works at Helvick.
Any proposals which the local authority wishes to put forward will be considered carefully having regard, inter alia, to available funding mechanisms and overall infrastructure investment priorities.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: his views on the major reduction in white fish landings; and the proposals, if any, he has to deal with the situation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: Analysis of the data for whitefish landings 1995 to date, for the primary whitefish fishing period January to October shows a fairly constant level of catch over this timeframe. While there have been marginal changes in the overall level of landings from year to year, there is no pattern of significant reductions.

The key challenges for the whitefish sector are quality and continuity of supply. The whitefish fleet renewal programme is supporting the introduction of 31 new whitefish vessels into the fleet as well as investment in modern secondhand tonnage and modernisation projects. This programme is designed to deliver improved quality, competitiveness and continuity of whitefish supply, increased landings and better prices.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Offshore Exploration.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the latest information available to his Department regarding the extent of the gas discovery made by a company (details supplied) in the Corrib field; if his attention has been drawn to reports in a British journal suggesting that the find can already be regarded as commercial; the response, if any, he has received from SIPTU or the IOOA regarding the use of Irish workers and goods and services in offshore exploration activities; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The report to which the Deputy refers is the October 1998 edition of the North West Europe Upstream Report, which contained an article about the Corrib gas discovery. This was published by Wood Mackenzie and they have provided my Department with a copy of the article. They state that they believe that the field can already be regarded as commercial. However, on the basis of the data acquired by the licensees the Corrib gas accumulation cannot be regarded as commercial at this time. It is not known with any precision how much gas is in place or how it is situated physically or how it would be accessed. It is likely that two or three more years' assessment will be required before a full appraisal is completed. Only at that stage can it be determined whether the field is commercial. If so, it is then likely to take two further years to carry out development and bring the field into production.

MainHeading.P: It is Government policy to ensure that the Irish economy benefits to the maximum extent possible from offshore exploration activities within the constraints of EU legislation. I have continually impressed on the Irish Offshore Operators Association and the individual operators that Irish suppliers of goods and services and indeed Irish workers must be given opportunities to participate in such activities. In that context, as the Deputy is aware, my Department has written to both SIPTU and the IOOA urging them to discuss the problem of employment in offshore exploration with the intention of arriving at an acceptable solution. The IOOA has requested a meeting with me in advance of any such discussions and I have agreed to meet them. I have previously had discussions with SIPTU on this issue and am quite happy to have further such discussions.

I should add that Enterprise Ireland, under the aegis of the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment, has responsibility for ensuring maximum input of Irish industry in offshore exploration operations.

They have been very active in this area for some time and have assisted the operators in identifying Irish companies who can tender for work and have assisted companies by identifying opportunities that are arising in both petroleum exploration and production.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: if he will ensure that the Government approves funding to ensure that all fishing vessels have emergency position indicating radio beacons.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: Under the Government's programme for renewal of the whitefish fleet, grant aid is available for improving the overall safety standard of the fleet. The programme provides grant aid of 50 per cent of the eligible cost of the purchase and fitting of safety equipment.

Eligibility for funding under this scheme is based on the following criteria: (a) the items of safety equipment selected for purchase and fitting must be from a specified list. This list includes emergency position indicating radio beacons (EPIRB) and (b) the vessel which is being fitted with the safety items is sound, seaworthy, and must comply with statutory life saving and fire fighting regulations.

To date, there have been three tranches of approvals for vessel safety applicants. These amount to a total cost of £131,211.77 in funding, £59,050.45 of which, is EU grant aided. I will announce further approvals of grant aid for the purchase of safety equipment under the programme and would encourage the maximum number of fishermen to avail of this scheme.

In addition to the provision of grant aid for EPIRB's, I propose at an early date to introduce new rules, which will make mandatory the carriage of EPIRB's and other radio communications equipment on all fishing vessels and provide for strict enforcement through regular inspections of the radio communications equipment at an early date.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: if he has received the report of the task force on radioactive dumping in the Irish Sea, which was expected in June 1998; when the report will be published; the investigations, if any, held into claims by a retired merchant seaman that an Irish shipping company may have been involved in the dumping of toxic and possibly radioactive waste in the Irish Sea in the late 1950s and early 1960s; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: As I indicated to the House on 4 November 1998, I have asked the Task Force on Radioactive Dumping to investigate the claims by a retired merchant seaman that an Irish shipping company may have been involved in the dumping of toxic and possibly radioactive waste in the Irish Sea during the 1950s and 1960s. I welcome the fact that this man has decided to put this information into the public domain. I understand that members of the task force have now met him to discuss the matter and that further inquiries are being made on foot of his information. My officials have also been in touch with the UK authorities to advise them of these allegations and to ask that they be investigated.

I expect to receive the report of the task force as soon as it has had an opportunity to assess this new information. As I have previously indicated, it is my intention to publish the report of the task force.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Safety at Sea.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: when the 1998 Protocol on Safety of Life at Sea will be signed.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: when the 1998 Protocol on Safety of Life at Sea will be signed.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 57 and 71 together as these are identical.

I presume the issue to which the Deputies refer is the implementation, in Irish law, of the provisions of the 1988 Protocol relating to the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea, 1974.

My Department has prepared a draft statutory instrument to give full effect to the provisions of the 1988 Protocol. These draft regulations are currently being settled in the Attorney General's Office, and I intend to introduce them once settlement has been completed by that office.

MainHeading.P: When these regulations are in place, giving the terms of the 1988 Protocol full effect in national law, Ireland will be in a position to ratify the Protocol. I propose to then pursue this course of action with the Department of Foreign Affairs, which has responsbility for such matters.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the level of research undertaken to the effect mussel farming on the open seas may have on the macro economy of that area; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: Data from BIM, shows that, based on 1996 figures, the total farm gate value of rope mussels was £3.375 million which had an estimated value added to the national economy at point of first sale of £3.1 million. The gross output of rope mussels at secondary stage was £9.24 million with a value added to the economy of £5.415 million. This represents a total value added to the economy of £8.515 million.

Approximately 75 per cent of the rope mussel industry is based in the south west, with the remaining farms located in areas such as Mulroy Bay, Clew Bay and Killary Harbour. Processing of rope mussels is undertaken in Cork, Mayo and Donegal.

The bottom culture of mussels features strongly in Carlingford Lough, Wexford Harbour, Waterford Harbour, Cromane Harbour, Lough Swilly and Lough Foyle. In 1997 over 10,000 tonnes of bottom culture mussels were produced giving a farm gate value of £3.2 million with a value added to the economy of an estimated £2.71 million. An indicative annual return per hectare of foreshore is £14,000 for both rope and bottom mussel cultivation which significantly exceeds the return from agriculture.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: his views on the possibility of gravel extraction from the sea bed off the south and east coast; if an environmental impact assessment study has been carried out; and if the impact on fishing for herring and shellfish status in particular has been considered.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: Following a procedure which included the preparation and publication of an Environmental Impact Statement, a licence was granted in May 1997 to extract a maximum of 800,000m 3 of sand and gravel from the foreshore in Cork Harbour for use as backfill in the Lee Tunnel. Due to delays which subsequently arose the licensee was unable to complete the extraction work by the end of 1997, as specified in the licence, and had to submit a further application to extract up to 200,000m 3. Notice of this application was published in The Examiner in July 1998. The applicant has since reduced the amount sought to be extracted to 10,000m 3. Examination of the case has recently been completed and I hope to be in a position to make a decision very soon on the application.

An application was received to extract marine aggregates from an area south of Waterford Harbour. Notice of this application was published in July 1998 and an EIS was put on public display. My Department's specialists are currently examining objections (including those which refer to the herring and shellfish fisheries) which were received together with the applicant's comments thereon. I will take all aspects of the matter into account when coming to a decision in this case.

Bray Urban District Council plan to remove gravel from the Codling Bank to be used for coastal protection works at Bray. Approval under the Foreshore Acts followed preparation and publication of an EIS and examination of objections. The proposed dredge area is 0.255 Km 2 out of a total area of 200 Km 2 i.e. 1 800th of the area in question. Mindful of the concerns of fishermen, however, I have instructed that Bray UDC should ensure that adequate notice is given to allow for the removal of whelks from the proposed dredge area prior to dredging commencing. A liaison arrangement has been provided to ensure that the concerns of fishermen continue to be addressed.

The Department has received a number of applications and inquiries in relation to possible extraction of sand and gravel off the east coast. As these applications involve potentially much larger areas than those previously considered, and conscious of the need to examine them thoroughly and equitably, having regard to the competing interests of applicants in addition to issues such as the marine environment, fisheries and navigation, it is considered necessary to first establish a framework which takes account of different statutory and policy requirements. This involves extensive consultation both within my Department and with other Departments and agencies. This process has commenced.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: if he will provide further moneys in conjunction with Waterford County Council to continue the works which have been carried out at the boatcove in Ardmore, County Waterford, to make it secure for fishing boats and pleasure craft in all weathers; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The harbour infrastructure at Ardmore is owned by Waterford County Council and development or maintanance works are, therefore, the responsibility of the local authority in the first instance.

My Department provided grant aid of £45,000 to Waterford County Council in 1995 to support an overall investment of £75,000 in improvement works at Ardmore. The county council has not, to date, made a proposal to my Department concerning further development works at Ardmore. Any proposals which the local authority wishes to put forward will be considered carefully having regard, inter alia, to available funding mechanisms and overall infrastructure investment priorities.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the number of people employed in the sea fishing industry; the number employed ten years ago; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: Bord Iascaigh Mhara estimates that the number of people employed in the fishing industry was 16,000 in 1997 and the corresponding estimate for 1997 was 13,500.

These estimates of employment show the significant increase in employment in the fishing sector which has taken place over the past ten years. The expansion of employment, landings and value added in the sector has been supported by the structured programme of grant aid support provided under the Fisheries Operational Programme 1994-99. There is considerable potential for further expansion in the sector. I will be seeking further significant funding for the sectors in the next round of Structural Funds.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Afforestation Programme.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the measures, if any, he is taking to redress the imbalance between the 80 per cent conifers and 20 per cent broadleaf trees planted over the course of EU grant schemes for tree planting in Ireland in view of the fact that the EU average is estimated to be 27 per cent conifers and 73 per cent broad leaves in comparison.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The strategic plan for the forestry sector in Ireland, Growing for the Future, sets out an annual target of 20 per cent for broadleaf planting. This compares with annual broadleaf planting of 2 per cent to 3 per cent in the mid-1980s. Grants and premiums under the afforestation scheme are and will continue to be heavily biased in favour of broadleaves.

MainHeading.P: Comparisons with other member states are not really valid given the differing aims of programmes at the level of member states, the spread of climatic zones and the type of land available for planting. For example, in Austria the aim of the programme is to construct forest roads while in the UK the programme is used for environmental type of planting.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the consideration, if any, he has given to the merits of effecting the securitisation of the income stream from the State owned forest enterprises, through the NTMA managed company (details supplied) or otherwise, as an alternative to the option of privatising Coillte Teoranta which would necessitate the transfer of the largest single land bank into private ownership; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The strategic plan for the development of forestry, published in 1996, indicated that Coillte Teoranta would be maintained in public ownership in the medium term, but that the full commercial development of the company would provide Government with a wide range of ownership options in the future. I am keeping this matter under review.

All of the financial options relating to Coillte will be thoroughly examined before any decision regarding ownership is taken. I should add that the specific option referred to by the Deputy would require new legislation.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the investigation, if any, which has been held into the destruction on the sea bed off the Donegal coast of the vessel, Lisa Selena, which sank with the loss of two lives; the implications of the destruction for any investigation into the cause of the sinking; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: My Department, in conjunction with the Garda and the Attorney General's office, has launched a full investigation into the incident, whereby damage has apparently been caused to the vessel Lisa Selena, following its loss in tragic circumstances.

In addition, a marine casualty investigation, under section 728 of the Merchant Shippping Act, 1894, is being undertaken by my Department's marine survey office into the sinking of the vessel with the tragic loss of two lives. I cannot say, at this stage, what the full implications will be for that investigation arising out of the damage done to the sunken vessel. However, the investigation will fully address this aspect of the tragedy.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the estimated value of the discovery of additional land under afforestation arising from the new satellite based forest inventory and planning system; if he has satisfied himself that procedures are now in place to give an accurate measurement of land under forestry; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The forest inventory and planning system is a highly developed computer based information platform which has succeeded in identifying the national forest estate to within accuracies of 99 per cent. The recent inventory has disclosed the national forest estate to be 606,000 hectares. This figure is in line with the expected total forest cover for the country. An area of around 4,000 hectares, however, was identified in the inventory which was not included in earlier inventories. The maximum potential value of this area would be approximately £20,000 per hectare. The total estimated value of the additional forest estate on this basis would at a maximum be £80 million. The system, which lends itself to constant updating will be capable of producing accurate statistics on forest cover well into the new millennium. It is also noteworthy that this inventory showed the proportion of broadleaved forests is now 21 per cent, 1 per cent above previous inventories.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, his Department has to encourage organic fish farming; the benefit, if any, this development would have on the industry; if his attention has been drawn to the fact that at least one large British supermarket chain has introduced organically farmed salmon for sale; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: I fully support and will continue to encourage the Irish salmon farming industry in its strategy to harness the positive environmental factors at work in our marine environment to produce quality organic salmon.

One Irish salmon farming company pioneered the production of organic “Bio-Salmon” and has been accredited since end 1996 by the German Organic Food Certification Organisation and this product currently attracts a premium price in the market.

Sustainable and environmentally friendly production is the key challenge for all food industries. There is exponential consumer demand for organic products and all Irish salmon farmers will have my backing and that of BIM in developing in that direction.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the liaison which exists between Bord Bia and Bord Iascaigh Mhara in order to promote the overseas marketing of fish.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: I am currently in discussion with my colleague the Minister for Agriculture and Food on the future strategic relationship between BIM and Bord Bia. In previous replies I have set out my views on how the two agencies can work together effectively, as appropriate and without overlap, in delivering on their respective complementary remits. Enhanced strategic co-operation between BIM and Bord Bia is in the best interests of the Irish seafood sector as a whole. I hope to agree an overall strategic approach with Minister Walsh shortly which will meet the needs of both agencies and which will deliver for Irish seafood processors and exporters.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, his Department has to deal with the shortage of crewmen in the whitefish boats sector; if he will indicate the reasons for this development; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: I have already announced my intention to set up a task force on training and employment in the fishing fleet. The task force which will be industry driven, will examine the barriers to employment in the sector and will assess all the educational, social, demographic, economic and training factors affecting employment. I will be announcing the composition of and detailed terms of reference for the task force shortly.

Qst.Quest: the household income for each electoral division in County Meath as tabulated by the Central Statistics Office; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.P: Household income estimates are not compiled regularly by the Central Statistics Office. CSO is, however, in the process of preparing household income estimates based on a methodology developed for it by the Economic and Social Research Institute (ESRI). The intention is to provide, by the middle of next year, details at regional level with an overall estimate of household income for each county. Data on household incomes will not be published at a lower level than county, for example DEDs, because the underlying data are not available. For an example, some of the data used for the compilation of household incomes are derived from sample surveys which are much too small to provide results at DED level in any county.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: the position in relation to Sunday trading; the recent developments, if any, in this regard; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. T. Kitt) Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. T. Kitt)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. T. Kitt)
Speaker.P: The Shops (Hours of Trading) Act, 1938, governs the opening of retail establishments. The Act provides for a ban on Sunday trading for most shops but gave the Minister power by order to add to the list of exempted business, or to exempt specifed regions from the provisions of the Act. However, an order made later that year (1938) exempted the whole country from the provisions of the Act and effectively removed all restrictions on Sunday trading. This remains the position to the present day.
I draw the Deputy's attention to the replies to Questions Nos. 69 and 70 on 1 December 1998 on related matters.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to offer free Internet access to small firms similar to the British Government backed scheme; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney) Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.NameTxt: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.P: Although the British scheme has been endorsed by the British Government, it is a private sector initiative involving the UK Federation of Small Businesses and Internet providers. While I have no plans to offer free Internet access to small firms, I am aware that one of the small business representative organisations in this country has an initiative, in conjunction with two Internet providers, which gives 90 days free access and subsequent discount rates for members.

In addition, it is possible for companies to make details of their products and services available on the Enterprise Ireland and National Software Directorate web sites and on the web sites which have been set up by some of the county enterprise boards.

I am very conscious of the importance of lowcost Internet access as emphasised by the Advisory Committee on Telecommunications in their recent report. The primary means by which competitive Internet access prices will be developed in the Irish market will be through the development of a regulatory framework which promotes effective competition. I am liaising closely with my colleague, the Minister for Public Enterprise, regarding any developments in this area.
I was pleased to note the price reductions for Internet access recently announced by Telecom Éireann and I look forward to the introduction of a flat rate access in January next.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Building Material Imports.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: the number of clay bricks imported from the United Kingdom and Europe for the year 1997 and to date in 1998 to the equivalent of the Irish standard IS.98 (1983) or to BS.3921 (1985); and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. T. Kitt) Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. T. Kitt)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. T. Kitt)
Speaker.P: I presume the Deputy has in mind Irish standard IS. 91 (1983) which relates to clay bricks. The specific data sought by the Deputy is not available from the Central Statistics Office. However the statistics on clay bricks are included with those for building blocks.

In 1997 a total volume of 33,928,485kg (value IR£1,369,188) of building blocks and clay bricks was imported, with 33,384,669kg (IR£926,268) being imported from Northern Ireland. The volume of imports from Great Britain was 539,302kg (value IR£441,250). The volume of imports from Germany was 2,137kg (value IR£1,341) in the same period.

MainHeading.P: Figures are available up to the end of July 1998. A total volume of 21,662,779kg (value IR£973,019) of building blocks and clay bricks was imported. The volume of imports from Northern Ireland was 21,193,612kg (value IR£566,675) and from Great Britain was 389,295kg (value IR£403,795). Imports from France and Italy were 40,960kg (value IR£896) and 38,912kg (value IR£1,654), respectively.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: if there is a list of applicants at clerical officer level within her Department who wish to locate in County Kilkenny; the way in which this list is prioritised; the number of transfers granted from the list to County Kilkenny; if the list will be depleted in view of the new decentralised offices in Kilkenny; her views on the present system; and the changes, if any, planned in this regard.

Speaker.hpid: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney) Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.NameTxt: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.P: The Patents Office in my Department is located in Kilkenny and consequently my Department has a central transfer list for clerical officers wishing to transfer to that office. The list is prioritised by the date of application. To date, no transfers have been granted from the list. While people will come off the list as vacancies arise the list is unlikely to be significantly reduced in the near future as the Department continuously receives applications.

The present system operated by my Department is similar to methods in place in other Departments. The interests of staff are safeguarded as the system is operated with the agreement of the trade union concerned and there are no plans to make any changes. However, from time to time the system can be reviewed with a view to change and improvement.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: the number of personnel transferred to Kilkenny city as part of the recent decentralisation programme; the number of employees the new building at Hebron Road, Kilkenny will cater for; and the number that have taken up employment to date.

Speaker.hpid: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney) Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.NameTxt: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.P: The Patents Office of my Department was recently decentralised to the offices at Hebron Road in Kilkenny. Other Departments have relocated or intend to relocate staff to Hebron Road. In so far as my Department is concerned, the following is the information sought.

Sixty-two members of staff transferred with the Patents Office. The Patents Office at Hebron Road will have a full complement of 68 members of staff, so far 63 have taken up duty there. Recruitment of the remaining staff is at an advanced stage and should be finalised in the new year.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the problems associated with kerosene oil products which are dyed in order to distinguish them from other oil products; and if she will have an investigation made to establish if the dyeing of these products brings about a negative reaction which can cause fire and health hazards under performance.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. T. Kitt) Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. T. Kitt)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. T. Kitt)
Speaker.P: The adding of dyes to kerosene oil based products is a matter which is governed by regulations which are the responsibility of the office of the Revenue Commissioners.

The National Authority for Occupational Safety and Health is aware of reports from another EU country (Sweden) of health concerns relating to green diesel. However, it is not aware of any adverse health effects from exposure to green diesel in Ireland or of any other particular problems specifically related to the addition of dyes to kerosene. The authority has also pointed out that kerosene is a flammable substance irrespective of whether or not dyes are added. It is not aware of spontaneous combustion or a lowering of the flash point being brought about by the addition of dyes.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: the specific targeted new measures she will have introduced in the Waterford constituency in 1999 to promote enterprise, trade and employment; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney) Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.NameTxt: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.P: Government support for enterprise, trade and employment is implemented primarily through agencies under the aegis of my Department, operating a wide range of policy instruments, to be used as appropriate in any given instance. The continued relevance and effectiveness of these instruments is kept under constant review and changes are made as required. That will continue to be the case in 1999.

The policy instruments now being deployed are proving very effective in supporting the establishment and expansion of enterprises throughout the State, including Waterford, which I visited very recently.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: the role, if any, she has in job creation.

Speaker.hpid: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney) Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.NameTxt: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.P: The State, acting primarily through its agencies, supports the establishment or expansion of businesses, as provided for in legislation, the main expression of which is the Industrial Development Act, 1986, as amended. The primary role of the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment in this area is to contribute to the formulation of Government policy and to ensure the Department and its agencies implement that policy in an efficient and effective manner. The Minister also plays a major role in ensuring that the investment climate and broad business environment is conducive to the establishment and expansion of enterprises and that the labour force is well trained and flexible and operates in a properly regulated environment. I am also concerned to ensure that the labour force is properly incentivised through reform of the tax system.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: the trade figures between Ireland and Iceland over the past three years; the proposals, if any, she has to improve the situation; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. T. Kitt) Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. T. Kitt)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. T. Kitt)
Speaker.P: The value of Ireland's merchandise trade with Iceland totalled £13 million in 1995, £21 million in 1996 and £22 million in 1997. The promotion of Ireland's exports to Iceland is the responsibility of Enterprise Ireland and I understand from it that exporters to Iceland are assisted on a one to one basis.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the progress in relation to the centre of excellence for maritime training in Cork; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The report of the task force on seafarer training and employment was published on 19 October 1998. I have furnished the Deputy with a copy of the report. I am sending separately to the Deputy, for his information, a press release together with some press coverage on the report from that time. Arrangements are in hand to establish the interdepartmental working group which will be charged with examining the costings, financing and timing of the establishment of the new maritime college with a view to submission of a fully developed proposal for implementation to Government at an early date.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the position in relation to applications for mussel farming in Dunmanus Bay, County Cork; if his attention has been drawn to the high level of opposition to these proposals by the majority of local people; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: My Department is at present processing eight applications for aquaculture licences to engage in mussel farming in Dunmanus Bay. The applications are being considered in accordance with the provisions of the Fisheries (Amendment) Act, 1997. This legislation, and regulations made under it, provide a thorough and fully transparent mechanism for the processing of aquaculture licence applications. The legislation provides that the legitimate interests of all parties who may be affected by any proposed aquaculture operations are fully taken into account in the licensing process.

Following initial scrutiny of the applications by the Department, the public consultation process was initiated and the views of a number of relevant agencies were formally requested. These included: The Department of Arts, Heritage, Gaeltacht and the Islands; An Bord Iascaigh Mhara; The Marine Institute; Cork County Council; Bord Fáilte; the Central Fisheries Board; the South Western Regional Fisheries Board; the Commissioners of Irish Lights, and An Taisce. The general public was informed of the proposed operations by advertisements placed in local newspapers which advised that detailed maps of the proposed operations were available for inspection in the local Garda station. The advertisements also invited interested parties to make submissions or observations to my Department on the proposals if they so wished.

A number of submissions have been received in the Department and have been referred to the applicants for comment. The submissions received and the responses of the applicants will be carefully considered before any decision is made in relation to the grant of licences. As the Deputy may also be aware, under the terms of the current legislation, there is a statutory obligation to publish all licensing decisions. Within a period of one calendar month of publication, any person may appeal a decision, either to grant or to refuse a licence, to the Aquaculture Licences Appeals Board, an independent board established under the legislation to consider and rule upon appeals which may be lodged against licence decisions.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the licences and results of exploration for natural resources in offshore activities; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Fishing Vessel Safety.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the progress in relation to the recommendations of the fishing vessel safety review group; the timescale for implementation; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The Government attaches a particular priority to the issue of fishing vessel safety and I am taking steps to ensure accelerated progress with regard to the implementation of the recommendations of the fishing vessel safety review group, particularly in the area of fleet development.

The report of the review group indicated that in the absence of incentives for the renewal of the fleet there would be little improvement in the age structure and safety status of the fleet. Accordingly, I have given top priority to the introduction of the programme for the renewal of the whitefish fleet. The programme involves a grant aid support scheme and tax incentives for the whitefish fleet. The tax incentives are provided for in the Finance Act, 1998. The programme is designed to promote investment in the whitefish fleet with the introduction of a number of new and modern second-hand vessels into the fleet. In this connection, I recently approved over £12 million in State-EU grant aid supporting investment of over £50 million for the introduction of 31 new vessels into the whitefish fleet. I propose to shortly announce funding towards a number of modern second-hand vessels. In addition, a targeted modernisation scheme and support for essential safety equipment for vessels will modernise the vessels in the fleet and contribute to improved safety.

I would, in particular, draw the attention of the Deputy to the veseel safety equipment scheme under that programme, which provides for grant aid of 50 per cent for the purchase and fitting of essential safety gear. I have announced three rounds of approvals to date under this scheme. I consider this vessel safety equipment scheme to be of vital importance. The aim of this scheme is to encourage vessel owners to fit out vessels with specific on-board safety equipment. Improved safety equipment on board vessels can play a vital part in the ongoing battle to protect life at sea; the recent tragedies at sea bring home to us all the perilous working conditions that fishermen endure.

MainHeading.P: I am generally pleased at the high level of interest in the programme for renewal of the whitefish fleet. It underlines the appetite and need for reinvestment in the fleet right around the coast and confirms that the incentives on offer are proving attractive to a wide range of fishermen. I would nevertheless strongly encourage fishermen to avail of this unique funding opportunity to install vital safety equipment. I am determined to ensure that the scheme fully delivers on the Government's objectives to revitalise the whitefish fleet and to support safety, jobs and competitiveness in the sector to the benefit of our coastal communities.

Concern was expressed by the review group at the number of unregistered fishing vessels operating in Irish waters, many of which are small and in poor condition. The group considered that these vessels constitute a serious threat to safety and recommended that this situation be addressed. Under a special scheme approved by the European Commission, the position of previously unregistered vessels in the fishing fleet is being regularised. Over 600 of some 900 applications under the scheme have been approved for a licence and it is hoped that all of the remaining applications will be processed by the end of this year. The criteria under this scheme for registration require, among other matters, that vessels undergo a condition survey report in order to ensure that the vessel is safe and seaworthy. This represents a significant improvement in our safety regulatory framework and in our safety standards for small fishing vessels in particular.

Safety training, which is vital to protect the lives of fishing vessel crews in the event of an accident at sea, continues to be provided in an accessible manner through BIM's two mobile training units in response to demand at various locations around the coast. In addition, the construction of a new fisheries training centre in Castletownbere is nearing completion. The centre, which will deliver safety skills instruction to fishermen in the south coast region, is targeted to be operational in early 1999. The principal objective of BIM's coastal training programme is to generate a health and safety culture within the small scale fishing sector in particular.

Funding under the EU's small scale coastal fisheries programme has been secured towards a new training initiative aimed at the spouses and families of small scale coastal fishermen. It is hoped that the relatives of fishermen can exert a positive influence in the promotion of good safety practices on board small fishing vessels. This pilot initiative, which is being run by BIM in co-operation with Údarás na Gaeltachta, Comharcumann Inis Meain Teoranta and Meitheal Forbartha na Gaeltachta, will target 12 venues over the course of 18 months.

Considerable progress has already been made in the field of on-shore marine radio communications. My Department's Irish marine emergency service has arranged for the installation of new medium frequency transmitters at Rosslare and Belmullet with enhanced radio coverage and improved emergency response for fishing vessels operating in the Irish Sea and off the north-west coast. In addition, my Department has recently placed a contract for the installation of VHF digital selective calling, or DSC, equipment at coast radio stations and other VHF sites around the coast and this work is due for completion at the end of next year. Ireland will then be in a position to declare an enhanced area, known as an A1 + A2 sea area, under the global maritime distress and safety system, or GMDSS, which will facilitate automatic distress signal reception from vessels fitted with VHF DSC working in or transiting our search and rescue area of responsibility.

The review group identified a need for a substantial improvement in safety awareness among Irish fishermen. In recognition of this requirement, my Department's marine safety working group has published three practical information booklets specifically for fishing vessels. These user-friendly publications deal with machinery failure, man overboard procedures and emergency procedures . Furthermore, it is intended to shortly publish GMDSS guidelines for small boat users, including fishermen, in European waters. The promulgation of this series of safety information booklets can play an important part in fostering an ethos of safety consciousness in the fishing industry.

As to regulation and legal sanction, notwithstanding the ongoing improvements in the areas of fleet development, safety training, on-shore marine radio communications and safety awareness, a programme is under way to underpin the development of a safety culture in the fishing sector through the introduction of the comprehensive safety regulations recommended by the review group. The preparation of the proposed safety regulations governing fishing vessels is well under way. Regulations have already been drafted to implement European Council Directive 97/70/EC setting up a harmonised safety regime for fishing vessels of 24 metres in length and over. These regulations, which are currently being finalised by the Office of the Attorney General, cover, inter alia, construction, stability, machinery, fire protection, life-saving appliances and radio communications. Vessels under 24 metres in length will also be addressed by the introduction of regulations for appropriate size categories of smaller vessels operating out of our fishing ports.

Draft radio rules have also been prepared, specifying the radio communications equipment, including emergency position indicating radio beacons, to be carried on all sizes of fishing vessels. I propose to introduce these rules, which are currently being finalised, at an early date. I also intend to bring in new regulations for the crews of fishing vessels, which will cover safety training and increased manning requirements, in line with the review group's recommendations in this regard.

In the context of health and safety in the workplace, the Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment, who has responsibility for the Health and Safety Authority, is to shortly introduce regulations to give effect to European Council Directive 93/103/EC on the minimum safety and health requirements for work on board fishing vessels. These regulations which are being prepared in consultation with my Department, will provide for its joint implementation by the HSA and my Department, having regard to respective areas of competence.

My Department and Bord Iascaigh Mhara, together with the Health and Safety Authority where appropriate, will continue, in partnership with the fishing industry, to implement the safety programme outlined above. Our shared objective is to ensure that the priority now given to improving and maintaining safety standards will continue as a permanent and integral part of the management of our fishing fleet.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: if he has satisfied himself that labelling requirements in respect of farmed salmon are adequate to ensure that consumers will be aware at the point of sale that the foodstuff they are purchasing has been cultivated industrially rather than in the wild; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: I am advised that there is EU and National legislation on the labelling requirements for packaged products for sale to the ultimate consumer. These requirements relate to: name of product; quantity of characterising ingredients; ingredients list; net quantity; use by date; storage conditions and instructions for use; and name and address of manufacturer or packer.

No specific provisions are made as to the labelling of wild versus farmed salmon. Provisions are made to ensure that misleading statements or claims are not made as to the characteristics of the foodstuff, quantity, origin or provenance, method of manufacture or production. I am advised by BIM that this is intended to prevent, for example, labelling claims of farmed salmon as wild salmon. Both may be labelled as salmon.

I am not aware that there is any significant problem in this area but if the Deputy has specific concerns he should take these up with the Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment who has responsibility for the rules on the labelling of food. The policing of these requirements is a matter for the Office of the Director of Consumer Affairs.

Qst.hpid: Mr. G. Reynolds Mr. G. Reynolds
Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 101 to 104, inclusive, together.

The fish farm at Lough Allen is operated by Gaelic Seafoods (Ireland) Ltd., which is the holder of a licence granted on 10 August 1995. Regular inspections of both freshwater (land based) sites and marine finfish farms are carried out by my Department's engineering division under the Department's fish farm inspection programme to ensure compliance with all licence conditions. A recent inspection of the Lough Allen farm showed satisfactory compliance with all of the licence conditions. The fish health division of the Marine Institute also carry out regular inspections of land based fish farms. A recent such inspection showed the fish to be healthy. The licence is available for public inspection on request at my Department's headquarters in Leeson Lane. In addition, Gaelic Seafoods is legally obliged to report to the Department and the fish health unit in the fisheries research centre of the Marine Institute within 48 hours of the appearance of any disease or abnormal losses or mortalities and send samples to the fish pathology unit.
